newsitem.title: CANADA: ELAN Energy falls on gloomy outlook.
newsitem.headline: ELAN Energy falls on gloomy outlook.

text.p: Shares in Canadian heavy oil producer ELAN Energy Inc dropped to a new year low in busy trade on Friday after an analyst's report cast a gloomy outlook for the company's production, financial and stock market performance.

The report, released late on Thursday by First Energy Capital Corp analyst Martin Molyneaux, recommended investors sell the stock based on a deepening price discount for Canadian heavy oil, flagging production volumes, high operating costs and second-quarter cash flow well below last year's figure.
Molyneaux also said that under his estimates ELAN was expected to report a second-quarter loss of C$0.07 a share.
ELAN, one of the Toronto Stock Exchange's most active issues on Friday, shed 1.20 to 8.05 with almost 3 million shares changing hands as investors rushed to unload the stock.
"There is only one word to describe our estimates of ELAN's Q2 1997 results: ugly," the report said.
Molyneaux said he revised his 12-month target price for ELAN downward to 6.60.

"We would be exiting out of this stock at current levels," the report said. "We continue to believe management has done a good job but has misjudged operating costs and the direction of heavy oil differentials."
The spread between Canadian light and heavy crudes has widened over the past two months to C$6.50-C$7 per barrel, about double last year's levels.

ELAN Chief Executive Verne Johnson told Reuters last month the company was producing about 34,000 barrels a day, well below expectations, after poor operating weather early in the second quarter delayed drilling and production operations.
Molyneaux's report said the production level -- equal to that of the first quarter of 1996 -- had not changed from early June.

ELAN, whose main operating areas include Cactus Lake in west central Saskatchewan and Lindburgh and Cold Lake in Alberta, has had a flagging stock price since late last year when it failed to meet its oil production targets.
Its year high of 14 was reached in October.
As shown with Renaissance Energy Ltd on Thursday, investors displayed little tolerance for output levels coming in below expectations.
Renaissance had a major selloff in its stock after it revealed its oil production forecast was revised downward.
Molyneaux said he estimated ELAN's 1997 free, fully diluted cash flow per share at C$1.23, which would be a drop from C$2.33 in 1996.
He pegged the company's operating costs at a "relatively high" C$8.20 a barrel.
